title: Verified Purchase
content: That said, I've been pretty irritated over the last couple of years, because it has seemed to me that she's just gotten lazy, and worse, has been taking her readers for granted - ESPECIALLY with her most recent Cousins O'Dwyer and Guardian trilogies.  Wait - I DON'T own every one of her books, because I refused to buy books two and three of the Guardian set, since I'd already "read" them before, just with different titles..  She didn't even bother to tweak the plots for these books - they were just rewrites of the Stars of Mithra and Key trilogies.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on July 19, 2024

title: Nora never disappoints
content: However, I really really loved last year's The Obsession (5+ stars), and I disagree with the negative reviews of Come Sundown that compare it to Montana Sky.  I read Montana Sky when it first came out years ago and several times since, and it's just not as strong a book.  Come Sundown is set in the same state, and since it's in Montana of course it's on a ranch - but to me everything about this book is just better.  Roberts did a good job of fleshing out the characters, building the settings, secondary characters, and plot. Alice's story was agonizing to read - and it should have been.  In fact, my only quarrel and the reason for 4 stars instead of 5 is that Alice isn't angry - based on her character's early temperament, and her horrible horrible losses, I think fury might be the only healthy response.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on June 26, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: In a way, all of Nora's books are going to be predictable.  Don't we read them because we know there'll be an HEA?  I love Bodine's family - love that they are strong and successful and not disfunctional because of their family ties.  I love that Cal's family are such healthy survivors of trouble.  I really hope that Nora will continue to focus on the new, and stop re-writing the old.  Meeting a release schedule is no reason to write a weak book - if her font of imagination can't come up with something that isn't a re-write, I strongly suggest she just consider changing the schedule.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: I usually love Nora Roberts. Even if I don't love one of her books, I usually like them. I'm crazy about J.D. Robb, and those are some really violent books sometimes. This one just hit me wrong. The backstory on the kidnapping, rape, and torture of the aunt just sickened me. I could barely stand to read those chapters that covered the past. I will finish this, even though I'm finding it difficult to keep reading. Nora Roberts does craft amazing stories. I'm just finding it really hard to stick with this one, and I'm afraid I will never read it a second time. I can not recommend this one to anybody. I'm on day three, and not even halfway through on a book I would normally finish in two days...

title: Verified Purchase
content: It's a compliment to Nora Roberts that I'm convinced she didn't actually write this story.  It's hard for a story be both disturbing and boring at the same time, but this one was.  It started off being a compelling horror mystery with an interesting, atypical character in Alice, but, when the story shifted to present day, all that premise was quickly buried under the routine minutiae of daily life in an overly perfect family.  Yawn.  I couldn't even bring myself to give a second star for Alice and the horse, Sundown, who were the only interesting characters.

post_time: Reviewed in the United States on April 19, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: There's a classic -- and successful -- Nora Roberts romantic suspense formula. A strong, capable woman with a difficult past falls in love with an interesting man and must overcome the obstacles created by her past so that she can have a lasting relationship with him and a satisfying life. Some of those obstacles are psychological; others are, shall we say, practical problems -- like someone threatening her. Or him. Or both of them. The story takes place in an appealing location, usually a tight-knit community of some sort, where at least some of the characters have unusual and interesting occupations. And an animal -- usually a dog -- plays a significant role in the characters' lives.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2024

title: Great Book
content: This time, Roberts has modified the formula. There's a woman who falls in love. There's a woman with a difficult past. But they're not the same woman. And that makes a difference.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on May 1, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: The woman with the difficult past (in this case, an absolutely harrowing past) does not fully recover from it (and it wouldn't have been realistic if she did). The woman who falls in love doesn't have huge issues in her life, and there are no major obstacles to her romance except for the expected episode of physical danger toward the end of the story. Roberts even throws in a second couple (perhaps because she realized that the first couple wasn't particularly interesting?), but they don't have any huge obstacles in their way, either. And it all doesn't quite add up.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2024

title: Outstanding story
content: The appealing location -- a ranch/resort in Montana -- is there. The tight-knit community -- a large, close family that runs the ranch/resort and their employees -- is there. The interesting occupations -- a combination of cowboys and hotel managers -- are there. There's even an animal -- a memorable horse. The story is interesting, but it's not as compelling as most of Roberts' recent books, and I think it's because there are two central characters rather than one, and we never become fully invested in either of them.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: Nora Roberts doesn't need me to review her books here, nor to defend her against negative reviews here, but after reading some of the comments here, wanted to chime in. I loved this book, which I preordered automatically. I always preorder and read the "big Nora" every spring. Always enjoy them, some more than others. I don't usually get her "trilogy" stories, or haven't in many years, but I've read most of her work. This is a solid big Nora with its strong sense of place, well-drawn secondary characters and real-feeling family dynamics. I am also a big audiobook consumer, and often switch between listening while walking or cooking and reading on kindle. I seldom do the audio for Nora Roberts because I usually devour in a single day or two. In this instance my schedule sort of required the audiobook and it really worked for me for this book. Mainly because there's a key character who is introduced about a third of the way into the story whose behavior, understanding and conversation is very childlike and repetitive. Had I been reading, I would have for sure skimmed ahead, annoyed at the change to the expected snappy Nora dialogue. But the narrator does a superb job conveying the character 's challenges and I frequently had happy tears in my eyes as I rooted for this person as well as for the main and secondary love stories. This is somewhat darker storyline for a big Nora, but it really worked for me.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2017

title: Great "big Nora" consider the audiobook for this one
content: I love reading mystery novels by Nora Robert's because she keeps you in suspense all the way through the novel. Just when you think you know who the protagonist is, she turns and twists things around.

title: Verified Purchase
content: This story was researched and well written. Some of the scenes were difficult to read  but well written and necessary to the plot. It's a story of two women . The first woman's story starts before the second is born. The first has a tragic life. The second with love and security in the heart of a loving family. A family that stands together in good times and bad.  That care for the people they love and the community of people who work for them at their resort and the people who come there as guests. This to me is the heart of the story. As the story unfolds you can feel the way the family stays strong thru good times and bad.sometimes I wondered if things would end the way I wanted and in the end the the characters I had come to care about had a happy ending and the evil ones got what they deserved.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2021

title: Excellent book
content: Overall, I'd describe this book as "flat."  The plot is predictable; the characters are two-dimensional, the chemistry is peanut butter and jelly - they go together just fine, but it's all very predictable and everyday.  The horse has more personality than most of the people - and more sense too. How much brain power does it take not to go out and pick a fight with someone who tried to kill you?  It might be one thing if they'd happened to run into him, but no - these geniuses tracked down a guy who had been arrested for the attempted murder of one of them, so that they could further provoke and inflame the situation, and not one out of the six of them ever said "this is probably a bad idea."
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on April 10, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: The most interesting character in this book is Alice.  Her story was gripping.  The "present day" story did not fall under the heading of "interesting" until Alice was found and even then it was interesting only in the parts containing Alice.  I knew "Easy" was "Sir's" son when I first met him.  It was too easy.  Sorry.  And I felt like with Cal and Bodine, I was revisiting a mixture of other Roberts' characters.  And as one other reviewer pointed out, there are pet phrases Roberts uses that I wish she would change.  Or at least it "seems like".
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2017

title: A good one
content: I often feel let down by the endings of Roberts' novels.  Often, very often, she tells a solid story (not necessarily in this case)  and then she hurries to finish it.  It's like she's done and she wants to shut it down and move on.  I don't believe for one minute that Bodine would have freed herself as quickly or that she would have escaped unharmed.  It was just wrapped up a little too quick and easily.  Ruined the momentum of the entire story - what there was of it.  After waiting for this publication I was disappointed.  Perhaps part of the blame is that with Kindle I am reading so many authors who have really been pulling me into their stories; writers I would not have purchased a hardcover from.  But I have read so many better stories recently with more developed characters than what is in this book.  Really not up to Roberts' standard.  And the bad news is, Come Sundown is now not up to mine.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2024
